The only thing he got right is the definition of expansion ratio. The chamber pressure is determined by the diameter of the throat and the speed of the gasses is highest at that point. As the gasses expand down the nozzle they push outward against the bell housing which pushes the rocket forward. An optimized nozzle will expand the gasses from chamber pressure at the throat to atmospheric pressure at the bottom of the bell.
Simple stuff that i just learned.

But how do we determine the expansion ratio without the Throat Area? The formula to calculate the throat area is At=Ae/Expansion Ratio. I really need an answer to this so that I can do the calculations for my design . I hope someone will see this and provide an answer.

In the vernacular you've got it backwards the nozzle is where it connects. The throat is further down where it gets compressed and the threshold of the Bell is the outer rim where it empties into the atmosphere

A little on choked flow: In subsonic flow, velocity increases faster than reduction in density, meaning that up to Mach = 1, you’re increasing mass flow. In supersonic flow, M > 1, because you’re beyond the local speed of sound, there is no way for the flow downstream to “communicate” through pressure waves back upstream. So the particles begin to separate from one another, and the decrease in density overtakes the increase in velocity, reducing the mass flow rate. In space, you theoretically want an infinite expansion ratio. Engineers approximate an E.R. of 100 as basically infinity 🤔

Something important is missing here.
In air the best expansion ratio is tuned for the flow static pressure to match the atmospheric pressure. Some device do provide adjustable expansion ratio to adjust the output section pressure all along the flight.
In the vacuum, the largest the expansion ratio the better, but the gain gets smaller and smaller for very large ratios. Optimization is a matter of gain versus additional weight in this case.

To add a little:
Higher expansion ratios (as used in vacuum optimized nozzles) have lower pressure at the exit of the nozzle.
Vacuum optimized engines can have much lower pressure at the nozzle exit than atmospheric pressure at sea level. If these were used at sea level, the atmospheric pressure would push in near the end of the nozzle, decrease efficiency, and could cause damage to the nozzle. The ideal expansion ratio (and nozzle) changes with pressure (altitude) so they often make the flow a bit over-expanded at sea level to get better efficiency later in flight

since airplane control surface is operating on the same choke flow principle. So effectively that mean control surface will have the completely opposite effect when under super sonic flow compare to sub sonic, IE tilting the wing downward will actually increase lift instead of decrease lift. When a plane is near trans sonic speed, part of the airplane's control surface will be under subsonic flow while other control surface will be under super sonic. So half of the plane's control surface will operate "normally" while the other half will operate in the opposite direction. So it's incredible dangerous for a pilot to stay in trans sonic region, since the airplane can easily become uncontrollable. Go to either go full super sonic or sub sonic.

Great video but one small correction: the equation for expansion ratio is wrong. It involves the area of the exhaust divided by the area of the throat, not the other way around as you had it here. Expansion ratios’s are greater than 1, not fractional numbers. Love the animations otherwise.
